France is my best country, and that's a good example.
Every book is also categorized.
In other words, they have what they call collections.
Every publisher has various collections of novels.
They'll have a science fiction collection.
But they'll have a collection of so-called mainstream novels
or something that is the collection of a particular editor
who even has a name on the collection.
So this collection reflects this editor's taste,
and it's labeled that way and it's given a name.
So in a sense, everything is categorized.
But there's less approbation between the categories,
since everything is categorized under a name chosen by the, you know,
to identify this line of, this bunch of books
what the editor was actually editing them.
There's not so much stigma having a category,
because everything is that kind of category,
although everything is categorized,
the categories are a bit more equal.
Also, they give you a lot, you know,
they have much more respect.
They understand that a lot of everything is crap,
but there's no particular reason why a science fiction novel
shouldn't be as good as anything else
and still be a science fiction novel if it's that good.
And so while they do still pay attention to categories,
they do not automatically discount something
because it's science fiction.
Yeah, I was talking to a friend of mine this morning
who was over in Europe a few years ago,
and he said, you know,
that he'd noticed many books
by, you know, you over there translations,
but yet he had not read you over here,
which implied to me that you must be better known
or at least more appreciated.
Well, I just came back from three weeks of France
doing book publicity in Paris
and publicity for the record I made there.
I think, not only do I think that I am more, you know, relatively more known in France than I am here,
but I think that writers in general are more important in France than they are here.
Writing is more, literature is more central to the popular culture of France, say,
than it is to the popular culture of the United States in general.
People have a different attitude towards writing and towards writers.
there's a certain generalized American
anti-intellectualism anyway.
This does not exist in France.
In other European countries,
this atmosphere
of anti-intellectualism.
And so writers in general are
considered more important in France.
And I'm considered
more important in science fiction.
It's a deep
cultural attitude that reflects
partly the fact that my books are more popular there.
Partly the fact that
it's more important to be a writer.
Okay, what about,
just on this question of science,
how it's considered by the public and so forth,
do you think the movies and television
hurt the image of science fiction?
I mean, to be treated as a serious literature,
do you think they detract or hurt it?
Oh, I don't know.
I don't think they...
Not really.
I mean, the image of science fiction,
in that respect, has been very bad anyway.
I don't think the movies really add to the image,
but I don't think they detract from it,
either. If there were some better, more sophisticated
movies they might film.
As it is, it's just
kind of neutral publicity, people more
aware that it exists. I think it's positive
and it will prove to be positive
in the long range, because a lot
of people are being introduced to the imagery of
science fiction, with which they were unfamiliar
through these movies.
And if you look at the evolution in the
movies, you find that in the earlier science
fiction movies, if you're going into space
or whatever it is, you had to spend like half an hour
setting a thing. This is a spaceship.
but it takes off
from the Earth
people float around it
you know
you have to
familiarize the audience
with all this
unfamiliar imagery
now they can just
start a movie
bang
right off
in a galaxy
far away
boom
here's a spaceship
Nostromo
pow
you know
in other words
the first half hour
of the conventional
old time science fiction

because people

and I think
these movies
have brought a lot
of new people

they made these images

uh
These movies have been mainly aimed at kids and adolescents.
Ten years from now, assuming that these people ever read anything,
they will be ready to read science fiction of a more serious kind,
assuming they're ready to read literature of a more serious kind at all,
because they'll be familiar with the material, familiar with the literature.
It won't seem strange and weird to them, because they will have grown up with it.
That's why I think even magazines like Starlock in that sense
will have a long-term positive impact.
